Name: Dulcimer
Elements_To_Use: Bright harmonic shimmer, gentle plucked texture, natural sustain
Elements_To_Avoid: Aggressive strumming, dominant melodic lines
Adaptation_Notes: Use as ambient background texture layer, keep volume subtle for gentle brain stimulation without distraction

Name: Harp
Elements_To_Use: Glissando textures, arpeggiated patterns, soft harmonic resonance
Elements_To_Avoid: Complex classical melodies, forte passages
Adaptation_Notes: Works beautifully for alpha boost and theta states, use as flowing background element

Name: Autoharp
Elements_To_Use: Gentle strummed chords, open tuning resonance, folk warmth
Elements_To_Avoid: Aggressive chord changes, loud strumming
Adaptation_Notes: Creates soothing bed of harmonic texture, pairs well with fingerstyle guitar

Name: Celesta
Elements_To_Use: Bell-like tones, delicate high-frequency sparkle, music-box quality
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy melodic lines, nursery-rhyme associations
Adaptation_Notes: Adds gentle high-frequency stimulation for focus without harsh digital sounds

Name: Steel Pan
Elements_To_Use: Warm metallic shimmer, Caribbean resonance, mellow sustain
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy calypso melodies, fast rhythmic patterns
Adaptation_Notes: Use sustained tones and slow melodic fragments as exotic texture layer

Name: Marimba
Elements_To_Use: Woody resonance, gentle mallet strikes, warm mid-range tones
Elements_To_Avoid: Fast runs, complex melodic patterns
Adaptation_Notes: Excellent for theta-gamma coupling, use simple rhythmic patterns as foundation

Name: Vibraphone
Elements_To_Use: Soft mallet attack, gentle vibrato, jazz warmth
Elements_To_Avoid: Bebop melodies, aggressive playing
Adaptation_Notes: Perfect for focused work - creates pleasant mid-frequency texture without demanding attention

Name: Glockenspiel
Elements_To_Use: Bright metallic sparkle, gentle high tones, crystalline clarity
Elements_To_Avoid: Dominant melodies, march-like patterns
Adaptation_Notes: Subtle high-frequency accents for alertness during afternoon slump

Name: Mandolin
Elements_To_Use: Tremolo texture, folk warmth, acoustic shimmer
Elements_To_Avoid: Fast bluegrass picking, dominant melodies
Adaptation_Notes: Use tremolo as ambient texture layer, not lead instrument

Name: Bouzouki
Elements_To_Use: Greek folk texture, metallic string resonance, exotic timbre
Elements_To_Avoid: Traditional Greek melodies, complex picking patterns
Adaptation_Notes: Adds Mediterranean flavor as background texture in hybrids

Name: Oud
Elements_To_Use: Middle Eastern warmth, fretless microtones, resonant body
Elements_To_Avoid: Quarter-tone melodies, virtuosic passages
Adaptation_Notes: Use sustained notes and gentle plucks for exotic ambient texture

Name: Sitar
Elements_To_Use: Harmonic drone, sympathetic string resonance, Indian classical texture
Elements_To_Avoid: Raga melodies, fast runs
Adaptation_Notes: The drone and sympathetic resonance create excellent theta-inducing texture without rhythmic complexity

Name: Lap Steel Guitar
Elements_To_Use: Smooth glissandos, Hawaiian warmth, vocal-like slides
Elements_To_Avoid: Country/western melodies, twangy aggressive tones
Adaptation_Notes: Creates flowing ambient texture, works for relaxed focus states

Name: EBow Guitar
Elements_To_Use: Infinite sustain, violin-like bowing, ethereal textures
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh industrial sounds, aggressive noise
Adaptation_Notes: Perfect for ambient drones and sustained harmonic pads without percussive attack

Name: Dub Delay
Elements_To_Use: Spacious echo trails, rhythmic repeats, dub reggae atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy delay patterns, harsh metallic repeats
Adaptation_Notes: Creates sense of space and depth, use subtle settings for gentle brain entrainment

Name: Tape Echo
Elements_To_Use: Warm analog repeats, gentle degradation, vintage warmth
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh digital delay, overly precise repeats
Adaptation_Notes: Adds nostalgic warmth and depth without digital harshness, great for evening wind-down

Name: Reverb Plates
Elements_To_Use: Vintage studio shimmer, lush ambience, classic analog character
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh spring reverb, overly digital sounds
Adaptation_Notes: Creates professional ambient space without being too clean/sterile

Name: Analog Synth Arpeggios
Elements_To_Use: Warm synthesized patterns, vintage character, Moog-style warmth
Elements_To_Avoid: Aggressive sawtooth leads, harsh digital sounds
Adaptation_Notes: Use subtle volume levels for gentle rhythmic texture, Berlin-school ambient style

Name: Mellotron
Elements_To_Use: Tape-based orchestra sounds, vintage choir/strings, nostalgic warmth
Elements_To_Avoid: Overly recognizable Beatles/prog-rock clichés
Adaptation_Notes: Creates lush ambient bed with organic tape imperfections, excellent for theta states

Name: Granular Synthesis
Elements_To_Use: Micro-sample clouds, evolving textures, digital atmospheres
Elements_To_Avoid: Glitchy rhythms, harsh digital artifacts
Adaptation_Notes: Used subtly creates evolving ambient bed that never repeats, perfect for long sessions

Name: Ambient Drones
Elements_To_Use: Sustained harmonic layers, evolving pads, Brian Eno influence
Elements_To_Avoid: Single-note monotony, harsh industrial drones
Adaptation_Notes: Foundation for theta/alpha states, must evolve slowly to maintain subtle interest

Name: Vinyl Crackle
Elements_To_Use: Analog warmth, nostalgic texture, gentle noise floor
Elements_To_Avoid: Overpowering surface noise, harsh pops/clicks
Adaptation_Notes: Subtle layer adds warmth and masks digital harshness, creates cozy atmosphere

Name: Tape Saturation
Elements_To_Use: Warm harmonic distortion, analog compression, vintage character
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh overdrive, distorted peaks
Adaptation_Notes: Glues mix together with warm analog character without being obviously distorted

Name: Swing Quantization
Elements_To_Use: Triplet feel, jazz shuffle, human groove
Elements_To_Avoid: Overly pronounced swing, shuffle clichés
Adaptation_Notes: Adds subtle human feel to electronic rhythms, prevents robotic monotony

Name: Shuffle Grooves
Elements_To_Use: Blues feel, lazy triplets, organic timing
Elements_To_Avoid: Hard shuffle, dominant rhythm patterns
Adaptation_Notes: Creates relaxed rhythmic foundation that feels natural and unforced

Name: Polyrhythmic Layers
Elements_To_Use: Multiple simultaneous patterns, African influence, complex interlocking
Elements_To_Avoid: Chaotic clashing, overly busy textures
Adaptation_Notes: When done subtly creates rich rhythmic bed that engages without demanding attention

Name: Odd Time Signatures
Elements_To_Use: 5/4, 7/8, complex meters, progressive feel
Elements_To_Avoid: Obvious prog-rock clichés, jarring transitions
Adaptation_Notes: Used naturally prevents rhythmic monotony, but must flow organically

Name: Clave Patterns
Elements_To_Use: Latin rhythmic foundation, Afro-Cuban feel, syncopated pulse
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy salsa rhythms, aggressive percussion
Adaptation_Notes: Subtle clave creates engaging pulse without being dance music

Name: Gamelan Rhythms
Elements_To_Use: Indonesian interlocking patterns, metallophone textures, cyclical structures
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy traditional melodies, dominant gamelan orchestra
Adaptation_Notes: Use the interlocking concept with other instruments for complex-yet-hypnotic rhythm

Name: Field Recordings - Rain
Elements_To_Use: Natural white noise, gentle patter, soothing consistency
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh thunder, overpowering water sounds
Adaptation_Notes: Creates natural masking noise and connection to nature, excellent for focus

Name: Field Recordings - Forest
Elements_To_Use: Bird songs, rustling leaves, natural ambience
Elements_To_Avoid: Loud animal calls, jarring nature sounds
Adaptation_Notes: Subtle layer adds organic quality and reduces digital fatigue

Name: Field Recordings - Ocean
Elements_To_Use: Wave patterns, tidal rhythms, natural low-frequency pulse
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh crashing, seagull cries
Adaptation_Notes: Natural theta-inducing rhythm from wave patterns, adds depth and movement

Name: Harmonic Drones
Elements_To_Use: Sustained pitches, overtone series, meditative sustain
Elements_To_Avoid: Single unchanging note, boring monotony
Adaptation_Notes: Must evolve slowly through subtle modulation, creates foundation for other elements

Name: Sustained Tones
Elements_To_Use: Long notes, gentle evolution, ambient foundation
Elements_To_Avoid: Static single pitches, no movement
Adaptation_Notes: When layered and evolving creates rich harmonic bed for other instruments

Name: Melodic Percussion
Elements_To_Use: Tuned drums, harmonic rhythms, pitched percussive elements
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy melodic patterns, overly musical drum fills
Adaptation_Notes: Bridges rhythm and melody naturally, creates engaging texture without demanding focus

Name: Tuned Drums
Elements_To_Use: Tabla, talking drums, pitched toms
Elements_To_Avoid: Complex rhythmic solos, aggressive playing
Adaptation_Notes: Use as tonal rhythmic foundation that sits between percussion and melody

Name: Surf Rock (Dick Dale)
Elements_To_Use: Reverb-drenched guitar texture, vintage spring reverb, instrumental guitar atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Aggressive tremolo-picked melodies, loud energetic passages, dominating lead guitar
Adaptation_Notes: Extract the wet reverb ambience and distant guitar texture - think background surf movie soundtrack, not foreground performance

Name: Krautrock (Neu!)
Elements_To_Use: Motorik beat, hypnotic repetition, minimal evolution
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh industrial sounds, aggressive guitar
Adaptation_Notes: The steady motorik creates trance-like state perfect for flow, but must stay background

Name: Fourth World (Jon Hassell)
Elements_To_Use: Ambient trumpet processing, ethnic fusion, dreamlike atmospheres
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh brass, complex melodies
Adaptation_Notes: Creates exotic ambient texture that stimulates without demanding attention

Name: Balearic Beat
Elements_To_Use: Relaxed island vibe, gentle electronic grooves, sunset atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Club-style builds, aggressive bass
Adaptation_Notes: Perfect for afternoon refresh - maintains energy without stress

Name: Minimalism (Steve Reich)
Elements_To_Use: Phase patterns, gradual process, hypnotic repetition
Elements_To_Avoid: Academic rigidity, harsh timbres
Adaptation_Notes: The phasing creates engaging brain entrainment, but must use warm timbres

Name: Space Music (Michael Stearns)
Elements_To_Use: Deep ambient exploration, cosmic atmospheres, theta-inducing textures
Elements_To_Avoid: New-age clichés, overly mystical elements
Adaptation_Notes: Creates deep focus states through slow evolution and rich harmonics

Name: Ambient Dub (The Orb)
Elements_To_Use: Spacious delays, gentle bass pulse, samples as texture
Elements_To_Avoid: Busy breakbeats, aggressive bass
Adaptation_Notes: Extract the spaciousness and gentle pulse, leave the dance-floor energy

Name: Lo-Fi Hip Hop
Elements_To_Use: Warm vinyl texture, gentle beats, study atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Dominant drum loops, sample-based melodies
Adaptation_Notes: Use the production aesthetic (warmth, subtle imperfection) not the genre clichés

Name: Exotica (Martin Denny)
Elements_To_Use: Tropical bird calls, vibraphone, jungle atmospheres
Elements_To_Avoid: Kitschy stereotypes, busy arrangements
Adaptation_Notes: The exotic instrumentation and found sounds create interest, but must stay background

Name: Kosmische Musik (Tangerine Dream)
Elements_To_Use: Analog sequencer patterns, Berlin-school ambience, evolving synth textures
Elements_To_Avoid: Harsh vintage synth sounds, overly repetitive sequences
Adaptation_Notes: Use the hypnotic evolution and warm analog character for theta states

Name: Jazzanova
Elements_To_Use: Broken beat rhythms, jazz instrumentation, smooth grooves, organic production
Elements_To_Avoid: Vocal features, dramatic builds, attention-demanding solos
Adaptation_Notes: Jazzanova blends jazz warmth with electronic precision - use the laid-back grooves and acoustic instruments over downtempo beats, avoid their more upbeat club tracks

Name: Fila Brazillia
Elements_To_Use: Atmospheric textures, dub influences, analog warmth, hypnotic loops
Elements_To_Avoid: Dark/heavy basslines, dramatic tension, experimental noise
Adaptation_Notes: Fila Brazillia creates spacious, dubbed-out electronica - use the ambient textures and subtle rhythms, avoid their heavier trip-hop moments

Name: St. Germain
Elements_To_Use: Four-on-floor pulse, jazz samples, Rhodes textures, French touch production
Elements_To_Avoid: Club-style builds, prominent trumpet solos, energetic sections
Adaptation_Notes: St. Germain pioneered jazz house - use the gentle house pulse with jazz instrumentation as background flow, avoid the more dancefloor-focused moments

Name: Thunderball
Elements_To_Use: Cinematic strings, vintage organ, retro production, medium tempos
Elements_To_Avoid: Dramatic orchestral swells, spy-movie intensity, vocal features
Adaptation_Notes: Thunderball does cinematic lounge - use the retro instrumentation and warm production as sophisticated background, avoid dramatic cinematic moments

Name: Blue Six
Elements_To_Use: Deep house grooves, Rhodes piano, warm bass, jazzy chords
Elements_To_Avoid: Soulful vocals (use instrumental versions), club energy
Adaptation_Notes: Blue Six makes sophisticated deep house - use the instrumental versions with Rhodes and warm house grooves, avoid vocal tracks that demand attention

Name: Peter Schmalfuss (Classical Piano)
Elements_To_Use: Solo piano textures, classical harmony, gentle dynamics, contemplative pieces
Elements_To_Avoid: Dramatic romantic pieces, loud fortissimo passages, attention-demanding virtuosity
Adaptation_Notes: Classical piano as background - use gentle Bach, Satie, or minimalist pieces, avoid dramatic Romantic-era showpieces. Focus on pieces that create atmosphere rather than demand attention

Name: Stan Getz (Bossa Nova)
Elements_To_Use: Bossa nova rhythms, cool jazz tone, gentle saxophone texture, Latin grooves
Elements_To_Avoid: Bebop complexity, aggressive blowing, foreground saxophone solos
Adaptation_Notes: Stan Getz bossa nova era - use the gentle Latin grooves and saxophone as atmospheric texture (like we already do), avoid bebop/hard bop intensity

Name: Breeder
Elements_To_Use: Minimal beats, atmospheric pads, subtle melodies, organic textures
Elements_To_Avoid: Experimental elements, glitchy production, dramatic changes
Adaptation_Notes: Breeder creates minimal downtempo - use the subtle atmospheres and gentle beats, maintain consistency without experimental departures

Name: Digital Analog Band
Elements_To_Use: Live instrumentation, house grooves, organic production, jazz elements
Elements_To_Avoid: Energetic builds, party atmosphere, prominent vocals
Adaptation_Notes: Digital Analog Band blends live jazz with house - use the organic grooves and warm production, avoid their more energetic club tracks

Name: A Forest Mighty Black
Elements_To_Use: Deep minimal house, ambient textures, jazz instrumentation, spacious production
Elements_To_Avoid: Club dynamics, dramatic builds, foreground elements
Adaptation_Notes: Deep ambient house with jazz - use the minimal grooves and spacious production as background flow, keep everything understated

Name: The Ventures (Surf Instrumental)
Elements_To_Use: Reverb guitar textures, tremolo picking as ambient layer, vintage spring reverb atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Dominant melodic riffs, twangy aggressive leads, surf clichés (Wipeout drums)
Adaptation_Notes: Unlike Dick Dale (pure surf), The Ventures do melodic instrumentals - use the reverb wash and tremolo texture as background ambience, not the melodies themselves. Think distant beach soundtrack.

Name: Donald Fagen (The Nightfly)
Elements_To_Use: Studio perfectionism, jazz chord progressions, Fender Rhodes textures, pristine engineering
Elements_To_Avoid: Vocals, complex narrative lyrics, attention-demanding solos, sardonic hooks
Adaptation_Notes: Donald Fagen's solo work (especially The Nightfly album) epitomizes the sophisticated jazz-rock production aesthetic - extract the lush chord voicings, Rhodes/Wurlitzer pads, and pristine studio engineering. The Nightfly has the perfect balance of jazz sophistication and electronic smoothness. Avoid Steely Dan's lyrical complexity and vocal hooks which demand attention - focus on Fagen's instrumental production mastery.

Name: Peter Gabriel (Atmospheric Production)
Elements_To_Use: Ethnic percussion layers, gated reverb on drums, world instruments as texture, sonic experimentation
Elements_To_Avoid: Dramatic vocals, emotional intensity, narrative lyrics, theatrical builds
Adaptation_Notes: Peter Gabriel pioneered world music fusion in rock - use the African/Middle Eastern percussion, atmospheric production techniques, and ethnic instruments. Avoid the dramatic vocal performances and emotional narratives.

Name: The Cure (Atmospheric Guitar)
Elements_To_Use: Chorus-drenched guitar pads, minor key atmospheres, reverb soundscapes, melancholic ambience
Elements_To_Avoid: Gothic vocals, depressive lyrics, dramatic dynamics, attention-demanding hooks
Adaptation_Notes: The Cure created lush guitar atmospheres through effects - extract the chorus/reverb textures and minor-key ambience. Use as background wash, not foreground melodies. Think Disintegration album production.

Name: Sting (Jazz-Tinged Rock)
Elements_To_Use: Jazz chord progressions, upright bass textures, sophisticated harmony, subtle world music elements
Elements_To_Avoid: Distinctive vocals, lyrical complexity, foreground bass lines, pop hooks
Adaptation_Notes: Sting's solo work incorporates jazz harmony and world music - use the sophisticated chord progressions, upright bass grooves, and world percussion. Avoid his distinctive voice and melodic bass lines which demand attention.

Name: Debussy (Impressionist Piano)
Elements_To_Use: Whole-tone scales, parallel chords, gentle arpeggios, water/nature imagery, soft dynamics
Elements_To_Avoid: Dramatic crescendos, virtuosic passages, Romantic-era emotionalism, Children's Corner playfulness
Adaptation_Notes: Debussy created "painting with sound" - use the gentle impressionistic textures (Arabesque, Clair de Lune) as ambient background. Avoid the playful Children's Corner suite (too whimsical). Focus on Estampes, Nocturnes, Préludes for atmospheric programming music.

Name: Chopin (Nocturnes Only)
Elements_To_Use: Nocturnes only - gentle dynamics, singing melodies, rubato timing, nighttime contemplation
Elements_To_Avoid: Dramatic études, virtuosic showpieces (Heroic Polonaise), loud passages, Revolutionary Étude intensity
Adaptation_Notes: CRITICAL: Only use Chopin's Nocturnes for programming music - these are gentle, contemplative pieces. Avoid the dramatic études, polonaises, and ballades which demand attention. Nocturnes were designed as "night music" for reflection.

Name: Chamber Music (String Quartets)
Elements_To_Use: Intimate textures, conversational interplay, moderate dynamics, warm acoustics
Elements_To_Avoid: Symphonic drama, operatic intensity, virtuosic showpieces, loud passages
Adaptation_Notes: Chamber music is "music for friends" - smaller than orchestra, more intimate. String quartets, piano trios, wind quintets. Use the gentle interplay and warm textures, avoid dramatic moments. Perfect for sophisticated background.

Name: Edgar Meyer (Contemporary Upright Bass)
Elements_To_Use: Upright bass as melodic instrument, Americana harmonies, sophisticated acoustic textures
Elements_To_Avoid: Bluegrass virtuosity, fast picking passages, attention-demanding solos
Adaptation_Notes: Edgar Meyer bridges classical and bluegrass - use the warm upright bass textures and sophisticated harmonies. His work with Yo-Yo Ma and Chris Thile shows acoustic instruments in contemplative settings.

Name: Baroque Simplicity (Bach, Scarlatti)
Elements_To_Use: Counterpoint, mathematical structure, harpsichord/piano textures, moderate tempos
Elements_To_Avoid: Fast virtuosic passages (Goldberg Variations), complex fugues demanding attention, organ drama
Adaptation_Notes: Baroque music is mathematically structured - use simple preludes, slow movements, gentle inventions. Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier has many contemplative pieces. Scarlatti sonatas are elegant but often too virtuosic. Use slow, simple pieces only.

Name: Vince Guaraldi (Peanuts Jazz Piano)
Elements_To_Use: Simple jazz piano melodies, walking bass lines, gentle swing, playful but sophisticated harmony, child-friendly but adult-appreciated
Elements_To_Avoid: Recognizable Peanuts themes (Linus & Lucy hook), overly whimsical moments, Christmas clichés
Adaptation_Notes: Guaraldi created the perfect programming music before programming existed - jazz sophisticated enough for adults, simple enough to stay background. His Peanuts soundtracks are proof that "background music" can be artistically excellent. Use the gentle swing, simple melodies, and warm piano tone.

Name: Jazz Clarinet (Benny Goodman Style)
Elements_To_Use: Warm woody tone, gentle swing melodies, duo with piano, subtle vibrato, background texture
Elements_To_Avoid: Virtuosic bebop runs, squeaky high register, klezmer intensity, aggressive swing
Adaptation_Notes: Streaming shows both "Jazz Clarinet Essentials" and "The Clarinet" stations. Clarinet has warmer, woodier tone than saxophone. Use as melodic texture like we used sax in Prompt 41 (which you loved). Benny Goodman small group recordings are perfect reference.

Name: West Coast Jazz (Cool Jazz)
Elements_To_Use: Laid-back tempos, sophisticated harmony, vibraphone, soft trumpet/sax, chamber jazz intimacy, intellectual cool
Elements_To_Avoid: Bebop intensity, hard bop aggression, East Coast energy, fast tempos
Adaptation_Notes: West Coast Jazz (Dave Brubeck, Chet Baker, Gerry Mulligan) was designed for listening, not dancing - perfect for programming. Lighter, more relaxed than East Coast bebop. Often features vibraphone and soft brass. Streaming shows "West Coast Jazz Essentials" and "Cool Jazz Essentials".

Name: Johnny Costa (Mister Rogers Pianist)
Elements_To_Use: Jazz harmony, gentle dynamics, sophisticated voicings, accessible melodies, warm tone
Elements_To_Avoid: Children's music clichés, overly simple melodies, sing-along quality
Adaptation_Notes: Johnny Costa was Mister Rogers' pianist - like Guaraldi, he played sophisticated jazz in a gentle context. His Gershwin interpretations ("Costa Plays Gershwin" in streaming) show jazz piano that's intellectual but comforting. Perfect programming music aesthetic.

Name: Tropical House (Kygo Style)
Elements_To_Use: Steel pan, marimba, gentle four-on-floor, warm pads, beach atmosphere, melodic hooks as texture
Elements_To_Avoid: Pop vocal features, EDM builds/drops, festival energy, aggressive bass
Adaptation_Notes: Tropical House uses steel pan, marimba, and island percussion over gentle house beats. "Tropical House Essentials" in streaming suggests this aesthetic works. Use instrumental versions only - the production warmth and tropical textures, not the pop vocals.

Name: Japanese Koto (Traditional Strings)
Elements_To_Use: Pentatonic scales, gentle plucked textures, nature imagery (water, wind), meditative pacing, minimal sustain
Elements_To_Avoid: Traditional melodies that demand attention, fast virtuosic passages, ceremonial drama
Adaptation_Notes: Koto creates gentle, pentatonic soundscapes perfect for theta states. Use as ambient texture layer, not traditional melodic instrument. Modern ambient koto (like "Koto Dream" albums) shows programming-appropriate applications. Pairs well with electronic elements.

Name: Anime Soundtracks (Ambient Tracks)
Elements_To_Use: Emotional piano, string pads, gentle electronics, wistful melodies, nostalgic atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Dramatic battle themes, opening/closing songs, recognizable anime themes, J-pop vocals
Adaptation_Notes: Anime soundtracks (Miyazaki films, slice-of-life shows) contain beautiful ambient pieces designed to enhance focus without distraction. Use the gentle piano interludes and string atmospheres from Studio Ghibli soundtracks (Joe Hisaishi). "Lo-Fi Japan" aesthetic often samples anime.

Name: Ryuichi Sakamoto (Ambient Works)
Elements_To_Use: Minimal piano, electronic textures, silence as element, emotional restraint, contemplative pacing
Elements_To_Avoid: Early Yellow Magic Orchestra pop, dramatic film scores, experimental noise periods
Adaptation_Notes: Sakamoto's solo ambient works (async, 12, Coda) are perfect programming music - minimal piano with electronic processing, lots of space, deeply contemplative. Use his restrained, meditative approach, not his pop or avant-garde work.

Name: Indian Tabla (Rhythmic Foundation)
Elements_To_Use: Gentle rhythmic cycles (slow tala), warm tuned drum tones, subtle polyrhythms, meditative pulse
Elements_To_Avoid: Fast virtuosic solos, loud aggressive playing, complex ragas demanding attention
Adaptation_Notes: Tabla can provide gentle, tuned percussion rhythms. Use slow tala (rhythmic cycles) as foundation, not foreground solos. Works beautifully with electronic music (Talvin Singh, Asian Dub Foundation ambient tracks). The warm, tuned quality bridges rhythm and melody.

Name: Bansuri Flute (Indian Bamboo Flute)
Elements_To_Use: Breathy tone, long sustained notes, simple melodies, meditative quality, nature sounds
Elements_To_Avoid: Complex raga improvisation, virtuosic runs, classical Indian performance practice
Adaptation_Notes: Bansuri has an incredibly soothing, breathy quality perfect for ambient music. Use simple, sustained tones and gentle melodies - not traditional raga performance. Artists like Steve Gorn show bansuri in contemplative contexts. The breathy quality creates intimate, meditative atmosphere.

Name: Ravi Shankar (Ambient/Minimalist Works Only)
Elements_To_Use: Sitar drone (tanpura), slow alap (introductory improvisation), meditative pacing, spiritual atmosphere
Elements_To_Avoid: Fast jhala sections, virtuosic display, traditional raga development, tabla solo exchanges
Adaptation_Notes: CRITICAL: Only use Shankar's slow, meditative alap sections where sitar explores a raga with drone accompaniment. Avoid the fast, exciting sections. His collaborations with Philip Glass and minimalist works show ambient applications. The drone and slow exploration create deep focus states.

Name: Nay (Middle Eastern Flute)
Elements_To_Use: Breathy tone, mystical quality, long sustained notes, maqam flavors, meditative pacing
Elements_To_Avoid: Traditional maqam melodies, virtuosic ornaments, belly dance music, dramatic dynamics
Adaptation_Notes: Nay has an incredibly mystical, breathy quality - similar to bansuri but with Middle Eastern character. Use for ambient textures and sustained tones. Creates spiritual, meditative atmosphere without being overly "world music" cliché.

Name: Mbira (Zimbabwean Thumb Piano)
Elements_To_Use: Hypnotic repetitive patterns, metallic shimmer, polyrhythmic layers, trance-inducing cycles
Elements_To_Avoid: Traditional ceremonial contexts, loud aggressive playing, vocals
Adaptation_Notes: Mbira creates mesmerizing, cyclical patterns perfect for flow states. Different from kalimba (which you already have) - more metallic, more polyrhythmic. Zimbabwe's mbira music is designed to induce trance. Use the hypnotic patterns, not traditional ceremonial contexts.

Name: Andean Panpipes (Zampoña)
Elements_To_Use: Airy flute textures, pentatonic scales, nature imagery (mountains, wind), gentle melodies
Elements_To_Avoid: El Condor Pasa clichés, tourist music, overly recognizable melodies
Adaptation_Notes: Andean panpipes create gentle, airy textures with natural, organic quality. Use for ambient atmosphere, not traditional folk melodies. The breathy, multi-pipe sound creates ethereal quality. Modern ambient applications (like Inkuyo's contemplative work) show programming potential.

Name: Fingerstyle Guitar (Jorma Kaukonen/Leo Kottke)
Elements_To_Use: Spanish/flamenco-influenced arpeggios, melodic patterns, open tunings, repetitive hypnotic fingerpicking, nylon or steel strings as texture
Elements_To_Avoid: Strumming, power chords, rock riffs, constant melodic development demanding attention, virtuosic showpieces
Adaptation_Notes: Fingerstyle guitar (Jorma Kaukonen's "Embryonic Journey," Leo Kottke's "Vaseline Machine Gun") creates intricate patterns that can work as EITHER foreground or background. Key: use repetitive patterns rather than constantly developing melodies. Works beautifully solo (pure single-influence) or layered with minimal percussion/pads. The Spanish/flamenco influences add exotic color without being traditional flamenco. For programming music: keep patterns hypnotic and consistent, avoid flashy runs that demand attention.

Name: Psychedelic Folk Instrumentals (1960s)
Elements_To_Use: Acoustic instrumentation, Spanish influences, open tunings, modal harmony, instrumental focus, vintage recording warmth
Elements_To_Avoid: Protest song vocals, traditional folk melodies, political lyrics, dramatic builds, acid-rock excess
Adaptation_Notes: The psychedelic folk era (Jefferson Airplane instrumentals, early Grateful Dead, Pentangle) created beautiful instrumental pieces that blended folk purity with 1960s experimentation. "Embryonic Journey" is the quintessential example - solo acoustic guitar with Spanish influences, no vocals, hypnotic patterns. For programming: extract the instrumental focus and modal harmony, use vintage production warmth (tape saturation), avoid the vocal-driven protest songs. Works as pure acoustic or with subtle electronic foundation.

Name: Spanish/Flamenco Guitar (Texture Only)
Elements_To_Use: Rasgueado textures (as background rhythm), melodic arpeggios, passionate tone but restrained dynamics, nylon string warmth, modal scales
Elements_To_Avoid: Traditional flamenco performance (too demanding), castanets, palmas (hand clapping), cante jondo vocals, virtuosic solos
Adaptation_Notes: CRITICAL: Use Spanish/flamenco TECHNIQUES and AESTHETIC, not traditional flamenco music. Traditional flamenco demands attention through dramatic dynamics and virtuosity. Instead: extract the rasgueado rhythm as gentle texture, use modal scales for exotic color, apply passionate tone with restrained volume. Think "Spanish guitar influence" not "flamenco performance." Works beautifully layered with electronic elements (flamenco house fusion) or pure acoustic. Artists like Paco de Lucía's contemplative pieces show flamenco guitar in meditative contexts.

Name: British Folk-Rock (George Harrison/Beatles Acoustic)
Elements_To_Use: Bright major key acoustic guitar with capo, melodic arpeggios, optimistic mood, Abbey Road production warmth, clean vintage 1960s sound, sunshine aesthetic, uplifting without being cheesy
Elements_To_Avoid: Recognizable Beatles melodies (copyright + demands attention), vocal harmonies, "na na na" hooks, overly sentimental production, psychedelic excess (sitars, backwards tapes)
Adaptation_Notes: "Here Comes the Sun" represents optimistic acoustic folk-rock perfect for Morning Warmup or Midday Refresh - bright major key guitar creates sunshine energy without being aggressive. Key: Use the FEEL (optimistic, uplifting, bright) not the specific melody. Capo-ed acoustic guitar, clean production, melodic but not memorable (avoid earworms). Works beautifully solo or with gentle percussion/strings. The major key brightness provides energizing uplift different from minor-key meditation or modal jazz.

Name: 90s R&B/Hip-Hop Production (Timbaland/Neptunes)
Elements_To_Use: Smooth programmed drums, sub bass foundation, minimal spacious arrangement, syncopated rhythms, confident swagger, clean modern production, bass-heavy groove, R&B smoothness
Elements_To_Avoid: Aggressive vocals, rap verses demanding attention, club anthem energy, overly busy arrangements, harsh digital sounds
Adaptation_Notes: "No Scrubs" by TLC epitomizes this aesthetic - smooth, minimal, bass-heavy groove with confident swagger. Timbaland and The Neptunes created polished R&B/hip-hop production perfect for background: programmed drums (not live), sub bass that grounds you physically, spacious minimal arrangements. Key: Extract the GROOVE and PRODUCTION aesthetic, not vocals. Use syncopated rhythms (not straight four-on-floor), clean digital production (not vintage warmth), confident pocket. Works beautifully for Deep Focus Block 2 - the bass weight and minimal swagger provide sustained energy without aggression. Instrumental versions only.

Name: Classic Hip-Hop Production (J Dilla/Pete Rock)
Elements_To_Use: Boom bap drums, jazz/soul samples, head-nodding groove, swing quantization, dusty vinyl texture, warm analog production, confident pocket, off-kilter timing (J Dilla feel)
Elements_To_Avoid: Rap vocals, scratching (too foreground), aggressive battle rap energy, overly complex sampling, recognizable samples demanding attention
Adaptation_Notes: J Dilla, Pete Rock, and DJ Premier created the golden age hip-hop sound - boom bap drums with jazz/soul samples, swing quantization for human feel, confident head-nodding pocket. The "Dilla feel" (slightly off-grid timing) creates hypnotic groove perfect for programming. Key: Use instrumental hip-hop aesthetic - the drums, bass, and sample textures without vocals. Warm analog production (not clean digital), vinyl crackle, dusty warmth. Works for Morning Warmup or Deep Focus Block 1 - the swing and jazz samples provide sophisticated groove. Think Nujabes, DJ Shadow instrumental work.

Name: Euphoric Dance/Pop (Empowerment Anthems)
Elements_To_Use: Uplifting major key progressions, piano house stabs, four-on-floor drive, empowering energy, celebratory mood, triumphant chords, building energy without dramatic drops, joyful euphoria
Elements_To_Avoid: Vocals (use instrumental versions), EDM drops that demand attention, cheese factor, overly commercial production, aggressive club energy, recognizable pop hooks
Adaptation_Notes: "Finally" by CeCe Peniston, "Titanium" by David Guetta, and classic house anthems represent euphoric, empowering energy missing from the library. This fills the gap between meditative calm and aggressive energy - music that actively LIFTS mood and energy. Use for Midday Refresh when you need emotional/energy boost, or Morning Warmup for empowering start. Key: Extract the FEELING (euphoric, triumphant, empowering) not the vocals. Piano house stabs, uplifting chord progressions, major key celebration. Build energy gradually without dramatic drops. Think instrumental house anthems, dance-pop production without the pop vocals. The euphoria should be sustained and hypnotic, not attention-demanding. Different from deep house (too minimal) or tropical house (too laid-back) - this is celebratory and empowering.
